â€‰ July 01, 2025Lead ImageWilly Chavarria Spring/Summer 2026Photography by Harry Miller At midday, before his Spring/Summer 2026 show in Paris, Willy Chavarria and the movement director Pat Boguslawski are briefing a phalanx of 35 men â€“ some models, many not â€“ about the opening sequence of the show. In a reflection on the dehumanisation of immigrants in the United States (based on horrifying images emerging from prisons in El Salvador), every man will wear a T-shirt created in partnership with the American Civil Liberties Union. 25Willy Chavarria Spring/Summer 2026 Chavarria spoke to the models: â€œWe're going to deliver a very strong message about the erasing of people,â€ he began. â€œThe name of the show is Huron, which is the name of the town I grew up in, in California. And right now, as we speak, my town Huron is being attacked by ICE.â€ His voice broke. â€œPeople are being taken away and put in prison. What we're representing here are the Brown and Black people, taken from their families.â€ Four hours later, those men would be kneeling, dressed in white, in a single row, heads bowed. As an image, it resonated wide â€“ it was also heartfelt, and brave. As is well-known, speaking up against the Trump administration can have repercussions for US citizens and visitors alike. But, in Chavarria's own words. â€œIt's always important for me to speak about what's happening â€¦ Everything we do, whether we want it to be or not, is political.â€ That said, this collection was not, aesthetically, dark. Rather, it popped with saturated colour â€“ spearmint, thick yolky yellow, a socking cobalt under the sloping, graphic brims of traditional black Cordovan hats. The hues, Chavarria said, came from the humble uniforms of warehouse and factory workers from around the world â€“ Colgate green, Amazon blue, the scarlet of Coca-Cola co. Willy Chavarria Spring/Summer 2026Photography by Harry MillerWilly Chavarria Spring/Summer 2026Photography by Harry Miller Here, they were elevated to high fashion, executed in deluxe, Italian-milled fabrics , whether a simple cotton or a blistered metallic cloquÃ© which, Chavarria said, was very â€œCarol Burnett â€¦ a bit Liz Taylorâ€. Indeed, there was a slant of mid-century couture to these clothes â€“ albeit via Palm Beach, with big Deeda Blair blow-outs over to a trio of ballooning gowns in Ikea blue, yellow and a hot spanked pink, and a slithery column with a pouched coccyx in a warty puce. But the same feeling could be eked out of a polo shirt, or bomber with cocooning back. Where did the impetus for all that colour come from? â€œIt started in a very superficial way,â€ Chavarria reasoned. â€œI want to do joy this season. I wanted to turn the tables. That was five months ago, six months ago. And as things progressed â€¦ the idea of what this joy means transformed. Now, what this joy is, is endurance. A sign of endurance, a sign of hope, a sign of rebellion.â€ And for me, in Chavarria's generous, joyous tailoring for men and women, there were unmistakable nods to zoot suits, the brightly-coloured, dandyish tailoring that Black and Hispanic youths wore as a form of protest through extravagance in the 1940s. They elicited violent reactions, too: in June 1943, in Chavarria's home state of California, what became known as the Zoot Suit Riots broke out, with American servicemen attacking young Latino and Mexican Americans. They stripped them of their zoot suits, ostensibly because they considered their profligate use of fabric unpatriotic against the backdrop of wartime rationing. In fact, of course, it was racially motivated violence, tinged with fear and loathing. History, it seems is repeating itself. Willy Chavarria Spring/Summer 2026Photography by Harry MillerWilly Chavarria Spring/Summer 2026Photography by Harry Miller Why did those suits excite rage? Because they refused to be silenced. They were about fighting erasure, about emphasising presence, about pride. They seem as prescient of now as they were of then.

So, im 17, a few years back (2022-early 2024) i struggled really badly with my mental health and bodily image, (Im trans MtF) and i ended up developing bulimia and struggled a lot with upkeeping personal hygiene, (just over a year clean from bulimia now and doing a lot better mostly), I got referred for a root canal about 2 years ago and completed it 6 months back, and since i have been taking extra good care of my teeth, (brushing twice sometimes 3 times daily, with colgate and an electric toothbrush, flossing every evening etc) and i have the 6 month checkup in a few days, and i am PETRIFIED. I initially got it done as i had a spot on the gum that kept draining then coming back. I got the root canal, then a crown fitted, and i havent experienced any symptoms (no drainage, no swelling, no new spot, no sensetivity, etc) however during anxiety episodes the last few weeks, ive had a very light dull ache in my mouth, at random spots in my mouth, which goes away when i am not thinking about it. I know its realistically anxiety, and i have had a history of physical anxiety symptoms (Ill hyperfixate on an illness, say a heart attack, and when i worry about it a lot i end up with chest pains etc) , it should be fine the success rates are so high, but the idea of having to have another 2 long appointments terrifies me, i have really bad hypochondria, im scared of needles, i struggle sitting still for long periods. the stress has brought me to a point where i am constantly worrying, its next tuesday the checkup. This is so obviously anxiety part of me thinks, but can someone please just confirm itll be okay? I am so scared its horrible. Any reply is really really appreciated and remove if this isnt okay<33

â€‰ July 02 -- PepsiCo has appointed Saakshi Verma Menon as the Chief Marketing Officer for its India Foods business. In this role, she will lead marketing efforts for brands such as Lay's, Kurkure, Uncle Chipps, Quaker, Cheetos, and Doritos. Prior to this role, Menon served as senior marketing manager for Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia at the organisation. She took to LinkedIn to announce the same. Menon is a marketing professional with over 15 years of experience. Throughout her career, she has worked with organisations such as Colgate Palmolive, The Coca-Cola Company, Uber, Nicobar Design, and Kimberly-Clark.

â€‰ Someone on Reddit said when Amazon has an inventory of something, they don't check the safety/quality of the products. They just dump everything together. So let's say they have 17 Colgate toothpaste tubes and 3 knock offs. They just dump everything together and then ship it out. Even though they have 3 annoyed customers they have 17 happy ones. This model is profitable for them. So you can do your research and make sure it is a reputable brand and still end up with unsafe poorly made products. Also Amazon will make their own products based on what their competitors sell that is successful. For example if they notice lots of people are buying a brand of stainless steel cups they will make their own and market it heavily on their website undercutting the competition. They may even remove the competition from the website. I just don't trust them at all.

â€‰ If you enjoy shopping wisely, you probably already favour buying in bulk. Not only is it a great way to save money, but it is also very practical and clever, because if you ever realise you've run out of essentials like toilet roll, toothpaste, or body wash, there will be more in the cupboard so you're never caught short. Our go-to place for great value bulk buys? It's always Amazon, which has a wide range of exclusive multi-buys that you simply can't find anywhere else in your usual supermarket. And with on the horizon (), there's never been a better time to restock your everyday household essentials, skincare favourites, snacks, and everything in between. Many of the early deals already live feature some of the cheapest prices we've seen so far this year, with big-name brands slashed in price, such as , , and . While most bulk purchases might not be the most exciting products available, they are the kind of items that tend to increase in price and are essential to our daily lives. As a result, not only will your cupboards be full, but your bank balance will also thank you for grabbing one of these budget-friendly deals, freeing up some money for you to spend on hopefully something more exciting. To save you from sifting through hundreds of sale items, we've done the hard work and compiled the very best offers available, including price comparisons, so you can see how much money you're saving compared to shopping at other major retailers. Find everything from toothpaste and body wash to baby wipes and dishwasher tablets, all at a fraction of the price. â€‰ Find the Perfect Fit: Expert-Recommended Hiking Shoes for Every Adventure Table of Contents Published: July 4, 2025 by Alexa Mellardo There's nothing quite like hitting a challenging nature trail. Whether you're navigating sandy dunes or winding through wildflower-lined mountain paths, the right footwear is essential for an enjoyable experience. To help you find the best hiking shoes for your next adventure, we spoke with outdoor enthusiasts and experienced hikers. What to Look for in Hiking Shoes Shopping for hiking shoes requires considering several key factors.â€ A great pair needs to be lightweight, waterproof, provide stability, and look good,â€ says Alison F. Heisler,hiking enthusiast,former D1 lacrosse athlete at Colgate,and founding member of LaunchBreak. â€œIt's a small detail, but the laces are critically important â€“ they shouldn't fray and need to tighten securely. I have narrow feet, so I need to ensure my foot doesn't slip inside the boot. Also, the best boots are always aligned with the socks you plan to wear. I use lighter-weight wool socks for trekking and running socks for trail runs, so I always try boots on with my socks.â€ Stephanie Beale, outdoor enthusiast and owner of GoatsTrail.com, adds another pro tip: break in your shoes before hitting the trails. â€œI prefer to wear them around the house or in the yard for a few hours,â€ she explains. â€œI don't like to start a long hike with brand new shoes without knowing how they'll feel after extended wear. If I can comfortably wear them for a few hours during normal walking, I know they'll likely be good for a longer hike.â€ Now, let's explore some top-rated hiking boots and shoes, as recommended by passionate hikers. 1. Salomon X Ultra 360 Mid Gore-tex Salomon's X Ultra 360 Mid Gore-Tex is a popular choice, praised for its rugged outsole, sleek design, waterproof membrane, and comfortable fit. â€œThis was my go-to boot for a recent 10-day trek in bolivia through the Andes mountains,â€ Alison shares. â€œThe terrain was uneven and we hiked through a lot of rain. This boot kept my foot dry, and I felt extremely stable. I didn't get a single blister!â€ RELATED: 6 Best Walking Workouts You Can Do on Your Local Track 2. Salewa Pedroc Air The Salewa Pedroc Air offers a lightweight and breathable design specifically for female hikers.â€ I love these hiking shoes,â€ says Alison. â€œThey excel in so many areas. I wore them almost every day during my 25-day trek to Everest Base Camp and throughout Sagarmatha National Park in Nepal.They're lightweight, below the ankle, and Grace O'Connor â€” Health & Science Editor Grace O'Connor ensures every medical claim is grounded in peer-reviewed research. A Master of Public Health graduate from Trinity College Dublin and former The Lancet news editor, she drives Archyworldys content that wins Google â€œHighly Citedâ€ badges and featured snippets on public-health queries. Grace also chairs the site's expertise review board for E-E-A-T compliance.

â€‰ Dartmouth College baseball coach Bob Whalen this week announced his retirement after 36 years and 653 wins, the most of any Ivy League baseball coach at a single institution. Whalen, the longest-tenured Division I head coach at one school, won 11 Ivy League Red Rolfe Division titles, two Ivy League crowns, and his teams made two NCAA Tournament appearances. Since Whalen took over, Dartmouth has had 31 Major League Baseball draft picks, with six reaching the majors. Before his arrival at Dartmouth, Whalen was an assistant at the University of Maine from 1982-89 and was promoted to associate head coach in 1987. A successor has yet to be announced. UNH soccer team to open Aug. 21 at home The UNH men's soccer team, which fell short of making the NCAA Tournament last season for the first time in nine seasons, will play Boston University on Thursday, Aug. 21 (3 p.m.) at Wildcat Stadium in its home opener, it was announced this week. The Wildcats will play a total of 16 games, split evenly between home and road. After the BU game, UNH will stay at home to face Colgate on Sunday, Aug. 24, and will then hit the road for three straight games, at St. John's, Western Michigan and UC Irvine. A highlight of the schedule is the annual Granite State battle with Dartmouth, this season on Sept. 20 in Durham. The Wildcats finished 7-3-7 last fall and won the America East regular-season championship. Vermont won the America East tournament title and eventually the national championship, 2-1 in overtime, over Marshall. UNH 2025 schedule Thursday, Aug. 21: Boston U., 3 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 24: Colgate, 5 p.m. Thursday, Aug. 28: at St. John's, 7 p.m. Monday, Sept. 1: at Western Michigan, 2 p.m. Friday, Sept. 5: at UC Irvine, 9 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 13: UMass, 6 p.m. Tuesday, Sept. 16: at Harvard, 7 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 20: Dartmouth, 6 p.m. Tuesday, Sept. 23: at Yale, 6 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 27: at Binghamton, 3 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 4: Albany, 7 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 11: at UMBC, 7 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 18: Vermont, 6 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 25: NJIT, 7 p.m. Friday, Oct. 31: at UMass Lowell, 6 p.m. Tuesday, Nov. 4: Bryant, 6 p.m.

â€‰ If the main issue is the mint in the dental products, could you try a product marketed towards kids? My 12 year old son is AuDHD and can't use mint because no matter how mild, it's a sensation he cannot handle. I Googled a lot a few years ago, because he also didn't care for all of the bubblgum flavors marketed to kids, and we ended up on Hello products. They have fruit flavors both with and without fluoride and we've successfully used most of them. He really likes the Mermaid (orange dreamcicle) and Dragon (blue raspberry) flavors, but grape and strawberry were well received too. They are more expensive than a tube of crest or Colgate, but to me it's more than worth it. I've gotten them from Target, Amazon, and Sam's Club.

â€‰ Subject: Vision Across Time â€” Project Pegasus, Plasma, and the Continuing Human Quest Dear Mr. Schatzkin, Thank you for your work preserving the legacy of Philo Farnsworth. Your reflections on television as the culmination of a 4,000-year quest for vision â€” from oracles to electron beams â€” are deeply resonant. I wanted to share with you the story of Andrew D. Basiago, an attorney and whistleblower who claims to have participated in Project Pegasus, a classified U.S. time-space program in the early 1970s. He was one of several child participants trained in eight different modalities of time travel and teleportation. One of these involved a plasma confinement chamber built by Dr. Stirling Colgate, located in a brick building at Kitchell Memorial Presbyterian Church in New Jersey â€” a site now used as a daycare center. I've written to Pastor Hannah Faye Allred regarding this. In 1972, Andrew traveled to Gettysburg on November 19, 1863, witnessing President Lincoln before the Gettysburg Address. When the Quantum Field Effect wore off, he returned â€” still wearing a coat and shoes given to him by John Lawrence Burns, a Civil War hero. This suggests that physical matter can move through time. I've also contacted the Newtown, CT Police Department and Rabbi Praver, a first responder at Sandy Hook, to share information about Andrew's testimony and its broader implications. Andrew is an associate of futurist attorney Alfred Lambremont Webre. â€¢ Andrew Basiago: andy@andy2028.com â€¢ Alfred Webre: alfred@exopolitics.com Andrew ran for President in 2016 and is planning to run again in 2028. His proposals, which emphasize disclosure and technological transparency, are available online. I find it fascinating that plasmaâ€”a medium central to early television and fusion energyâ€”was used in time travel. The body contains deuterium, the same isotope used in fusion reactors. The connections between plasma, energy, and consciousness may run deeper than we realize. Given your interest in the evolution of vision and technology, I thought this might intrigue you. Warm regards, Kevin Michael Purfield

â€‰ A sense of dÃ©jÃ  vu permeates the latest report on brand trust. Morning Consult's 2025 Most Reputable Brands analysis reveals that the companies consumers rely on most today bear a striking resemblance to those favored during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. This resurgence of trust in established brands underscores a continued prioritization of safety, security, and essential needs, even as the world navigates a new normal. The report, which surveyed consumers across all demographics, highlights a consistent preference for brands associated with cleanliness, health, and reliable service. But what does this sustained loyalty tell us about the evolving consumer mindset and the enduring power of established brands in a rapidly changing world? Across all consumer touchpoints, a handful of categories consistently emerged as leaders in brand trust. These include: Home Keeping and Hygiene: Brands like Dawn, Clorox, Lysol, Mr. Clean, and Home Depot continue to be cornerstones of consumer confidence. Self- and Personal Care: Dove, Oral-B, Kleenex, and Colgate remain trusted staples in daily routines. Health: BAND-AID and Tylenol exemplify the enduring trust in brands providing essential healthcare solutions. Packages and Shipping/Ecommerce: UPS, Amazon, the United States Postal Service, and FedEx are vital for modern commerce and maintain high levels of consumer trust. And, let's not forget the comfort factor: Hershey's and M&M's demonstrate that even indulgence can be a source of reliable satisfaction. Maslow's Hierarchy and the Modern Consumer These favored brands directly address fundamental human needs, as outlined in Maslow's Hierarchy. From physiological needs (food, hygiene) to safety and security, consumers are gravitating towards brands that provide a sense of stability and well-being. This isn't simply nostalgia; it's a reflection of ongoing anxieties and a desire for predictability in an uncertain world. Deeper Dive: Trust Across Specific Verticals Morning Consult's analysis extended beyond broad categories, examining trust within specific consumer verticals. Health Sector Trust Leaders Medicines: Tylenol Health Retail: CVS Health Pharmaceuticals: Bayer Health Services: Minute Clinic at CVS Health Insurance: Blue Cross Blue Shields Personal Care Brand Leaders Personal Care: Dove Dental Care: Oral-B Skin Care: Vaseline Lip Care: ChapStick Beauty: Bath & Body Works Cosmetics: CeraVe Hair Care: Head & Shoulders Gyms: Planet Fitness Hair Services: Great Clips Fitness Equipment: NordicTrack Generational Divides in Brand Loyalty Trust isn't uniform across all age groups. Younger consumers, particularly Millennials and Gen Z, demonstrate a growing trust in social media platforms like TikTok and YouTube, while older generations tend to favor legacy brands with established reputations. This generational gap highlights the evolving role of media and marketing in shaping consumer perceptions. Adweek's analysis provides further insight into these differing perspectives. Pro Tip: Building brand trust requires consistent delivery on promises, transparent communication, and a genuine commitment to customer well-being. The Rise of Health and Sustainability Concerns Recent data from the dunnhumby Consumer Trends Tracker reinforces the growing importance of health and sustainability for U.S. consumers. Two-thirds of consumers prioritize sourcing products that align with their dietary needs, and nearly half believe retailers should actively support healthy choices. This trend extends to a preference for local businesses and products, driven by a desire for transparency and connection. As the 2025 Edelman Trust Barometer demonstrates, trust is increasingly built through local relationships rather than distant national brands. However, economic realities are also impacting consumer behavior. With potential cuts to SNAP benefits and rising food costs, one in four U.S. households, and over a third of those aged 18-34, have been forced to skip meals in the past year. This underscores the critical role of food security and the need for accessible, affordable nutrition. The growing movement towards â€œfood as medicineâ€ is gaining traction, recognizing that food is not merely sustenance but a fundamental component of health and well-being....

â€‰ This sucks and I'm sorry. The other commenters are right that it needs to get done, but don't give up trying to find ways to make it more fun. It looks like Colgate makes a watermelon kids toothpaste.

â€‰ This is a continuation from the above story: Todd Pelino was a Power Broker at Cantor Fitzgerald which was located on the 107th floor inside of the North Tower. **Wednesday, February 15, 1967â€”Tuesday, September 11, 2001. **Â 34 years, 6 months, and 27 days. 414 months, 27 days. A total of 12,627 days of life. Kaleen Pezzuti was a Bond Broker at Cantor Fitzgerald which was located on the 105th floor inside of the North Tower. **Wednesday, January 31, 1973â€”Tuesday, September 11, 2001. **Â 28 years, 7 months, and 11 days. 343 months, 11 days. A total of 10,450 days of life. Matthew James Grzymalski was a Bond Broker at Cantor Fitzgerald which was located on the 105th floor inside of the North Tower. **Tuesday, February 21, 1967â€”Tuesday, September 11, 2001. **Â 34 years, 6 months, 21 days. 414 months, 21 days. A total of 12,621 days of life. ! [img](9i9zpwg3ydbf1) "Not a household name, not a famous man. A 34-year-old New Jersey guy, Todd was an ordinary American like you and me. But his is one of 2,996 names that will forever be connected with the worst terrorist attack on our nation's soil. Todd died on September 11, 2001, at the World Trade Center in New York City. Todd was a power broker at Cantor Fitzgerald. He was an all-American guy. Talented athlete. Graduate of Colgate University. Married six years to Megan Pezzuti. Father of two. In fact, that fateful day began with a tender phone call to his young son, as reported by the Rochester News: Two hours before the terrorist attack, Todd D. Pelino called his 2-year-old son from his office in the World Trade Center to wish him well on his first day of nursery school. The next time the Pittsford native called, he was telling his wife, Megan, that he loved her and their two young children, and he would try to get down from the 107th floor of the burning building. ''In some respects she gets some solace from knowing that she talked to him,'' said his father, Douglas Pelino." Kaleen Elizabeth Pezzuti, 28 years old, North Tower 105th floor"Kaleen Elizabeth Pezzuti was born on January 31, 1973 to Kathleen and Frank Pezzuti in Red Bank, NJ. She lived in New York City, NY. Kaleen attended and graduated from Rumson-Fair High School in 1991 and Cornell University in 1995. In college, she was a member of the Kappa Kappa Gamma sorority. Kaleen was known to be a loyal friend with a passion for art and playing soccer. She was a member of the Church of Nativity in Fair Haven and the Monmouth Beach Bath and Tennis Club. Kaleen had recently started dating her sweetheart, Matthew Grzymalski, in December of 2000. The pair had met working at Cantor Fitzgerald. On September 10th, Kaleen talked to one of her friends on the phone about Matthew, telling them, â€œHe's the one.â€ The next morning, she prepared for another day of work at the World Trade Center.Kaleen worked as a bond broker for Cantor Fitzgerald on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center's North Tower. She had started working for the firm in 1995 and made many friends there, including her boyfriend, Matthew, and brother-in-law, Todd Pelino. On the morning of September 11, 2001, Kaleen and her fiancÃ©, Matt, were working on the 105th floor when Flight 11 struck the North Tower, leaving their floor and all of Cantor's offices above the impassable impact zone. None of the firm's attending employees survived the attack, including Kaleen, Matthew, Todd. Though their lives were sadly taken on September 11th, Kaleen, Matthew, and Todd are never forgotten. Kaleen's life, love, accomplishments, and memories are forever cherished and remembered. "Happy heavenly birthday, WE WILL NEVER FORGET. â€‰ JSW Paints has announced a key leadership move with the elevation of Ashish Rai as Chief Executive Officer â€“ Decorative Paints. Ashish, who joined the company in May 2024, previously held the position of Chief Business Officer and has been instrumental in shaping the company's decorative paints strategy. With this new role, Ashish will now lead the entire decorative paints division, taking on full P&L responsibilities. His promotion comes as a recognition of the strong momentum he has driven in the past year, where his leadership has played a pivotal role in strengthening JSW Paints' presence in a highly competitive market. Bringing with him over 20 years of experience, Ashish's journey spans across diverse sectors and geographies. Prior to joining JSW Paints, he spent nearly two decades at Unilever, where he led high-impact initiatives in digital transformation, distributive trade, and B2B e-commerce across global markets. Notably, he served as Managing Director of Unilever Nepal and held leadership roles such as Global Vice President for Distributive Trade & B2B E-commerce. Ashish also brings deep FMCG expertise from his early career at Colgate Palmolive India and a strong grounding in technology from his stint as a Software Engineer at Infosys. His elevation underscores JSW Paints' commitment to scaling its decorative paints business and investing in visionary leadership for long-term growth. â€‰ JSW Paints has announced the elevation of Ashish Rai to Chief Executive Officer of its Decorative Paints division. In his new role, Ashish will lead the entire decorative paints business with full P&L responsibility, marking a significant step up from his previous position as Chief Business Officer. Since joining JSW Paints in May 2024, Ashish has spearheaded the sales and marketing teams for the decorative paints segment, driving growth and strengthening the company's market presence. His proven track record over the past year paved the way for this promotion to CEO. Ashish brings with him a wealth of experience spanning over two decades. Before JSW Paints, he spent more than 18 years at Unilever, where he held several key leadership roles including Head of Distributive Trade Transformation and Global Vice President for Distributive Trade & B2B E-commerce. During his tenure, he led strategic priorities in digital transformation and distributive trade across global markets, and also served as Managing Director of Unilever Nepal Limited. Earlier in his career, Ashish worked with Colgate Palmolive India as Account Manager for Modern Trade in the West and Area Sales Manager in Rajasthan, and began his professional journey as a Software Engineer at Infosys. Ashish's elevation reflects JSW Paints' confidence in his leadership and vision to accelerate growth in the decorative paints segment.

â€‰ The award-winning â€œMagic Duos,â€ out of home campaign reminded people that the combination of their favourite food and an ice-cold Coca-Cola is magic. When CEO Rob GuÃ©nette stood at the helm of a newly merged VML Canada, bringing Taxi and Wunderman Thompson together, he knew the easiest route would be the wrong one. Simply fusing old cultures from the separate firms â€“ Taxi having made its mark with influential creative and Wunderman building its reputation on CRM, commerce, data and tech â€“ wasn't going to be enough. He wanted to build something entirely new: a fresh company that could, from day one, be a serious contender on the national stage. OLG Ontario Racing Unfiltered, a gripping docuseries, brought the raw, behind-the-scenes world of horse racing to life, helping a new audience fall in love with the sport. And in just over a year, with over 500 employees across MontrÃ©al, Toronto and Vancouver offices, the agency has done just that through deliberate leadership choices, an ambitious vision and a culture that prioritizes creativity and connection. â€œWe established the leadership very quickly, so that set the tone,â€ GuÃ©nette says. And then he and Graham Lang, CCO, set one clear goal: â€œWe have to come out of this, not only with a successful merger, but also to land in the top five most creative agencies in Canada with a body of work that represents the totality of our capabilities.â€ Lang highlights that VML Canada ranked fourth in the Strategy 2025 Creative Report Card. The agency now consistently tops creative industry benchmarks. But behind those wins lies a deliberate philosophy that GuÃ©nette and his team installed from the very start: a culture of creativity, connection and integration. At the heart of VML Canada's approach is the philosophy of creating â€œConnected Brandsâ€ â€“ brands that meet customers with the right mix of humanity, persuasion and commerce at every stage of their journey. VML's integrated structure flows across three pillars, with Brand Experience, Customer Experience and Commerce under one roof. The company sees itself as a band of doers, innovators and believers in humanity. And for GuÃ©nette, those words are more than branding â€“ they are the spirit behind every piece of work, whether it's a simple in-store shelf talker or a national television spot, the commitment to high creativity remains the same. â€œPride Unravelled,â€ transformed data into a powerful visual statement and turned complex truths into an unforgettable celebration of identity and impact. VML's geographic reach is key to their success in a multicultural country like Canada. QuÃ©bec isn't an afterthought, for example, it's built into every national campaign from the start. In fact, some national accounts are run entirely out of MontrÃ©al or Vancouver, reflecting the agency's inclusive model. Improv star Pier-Luc Funk electrified the screen in San Ã‰mission, the award-winning comedy special that transformed a TV station's dead airtime into a four-hour overnight hit powered by the all-electric Volkswagen. This approach has paid off, with standout campaigns like Volkswagen's â€œSans Ã‰missionsâ€ emerging from the MontrÃ©al office, which won a Grand Clio for Media. A simple but powerful double entendre, the campaign transformed QuÃ©bec's TV â€œoff-airâ€ screens into a metaphor for Volkswagen's zero-emission vehicles, earning top global recognition and helping the automaker's electrification efforts resonate in a culturally authentic way. Other major accounts like Coca-Cola, Mazda, Fido, OLG, Vancity, Colgate and Kruger have also benefited from VML's distinctly Canadian storytelling. GuÃ©nette also explains that VML Canada negotiated significant local autonomy despite being part of the world's largest agency network, with over 30,000 employees globally. Technological innovation is also playing a part in the agency's future. Through VML's access to WPP Open, a proprietary AI-powered platform, the team can accelerate research and production without sacrificing creative quality. Though AI isn't a replacement for human insight, GuÃ©nette sees it as a powerful enabler. VML helped Coca-Cola Fuze make its Canadian debut with a bold launch campaign and introduced a fresh new brand with a familiar flavour to audiences across the country. Looking ahead, VML Canada's focus is on smart, sustainable growth. With a challenging economic landscape and uncertain global tensions, the agency is doubling down on deepening relationships with existing clients, strengthening their customer experience and commerce capabilities and applying their full creative force across every touchpoint. Ultimately, GuÃ©nette believes the balance between deep national pride and global connectedness is what sets VML Canada apart. That's why VML Canada's mantra is â€œFiercely local. â€‰ Colgate-Palmolive Company (NYSE:CL) is one of the Best Stagflation Stocks to Buy Now. On May 28, Piper Sandler reiterated its Overweight rating on Colgate-Palmolive (NYSE: CL) and held its price target at $109, implying roughly 18% upside from current trading levels. The reaffirmation followed a private meeting with CEO Noel Wallace and Investor Relations head John Faucher, which gave the firm a closer look at the company's strategic footing. The conversation focused heavily on how Colgate is steering through the current tariff dynamics, a situation the firm believes the company is handling efficiently and with minimal disruption. Piper Sandler described Colgate as one of the more stable names within its consumer staples coverage, citing its global footprint and shareholder-focused philosophy as core strengths. The analysts came away with increased confidence in Colgate's ability to manage international complexity, maintain consistent performance, and stay aligned with its long-standing emphasis on value creation. That blend of steadiness and strategic agility is what continues to anchor their bullish view on the stock. Colgate-Palmolive Company (NYSE:CL) is a global consumer goods leader specializing in oral care, personal hygiene, and pet nutrition. With iconic brands like Colgate, Palmolive, Tom's of Maine, and Hill's Science Diet, its products remain essential even during economic slowdowns, cementing its status as a defensive staple. While we acknowledge the potential of CL as an investment, we believe certain AI stocks offer greater upside potential and carry less downside risk. â€‰ July 08 -- JSW Paints has announced the elevation of Ashish Rai to Chief Executive Officer of its Decorative Paints division. In his new role, Ashish will lead the entire decorative paints business with full P&L responsibility, marking a significant step up from his previous position as Chief Business Officer. Since joining JSW Paints in May 2024, Ashish has spearheaded the sales and marketing teams for the decorative paints segment, driving growth and strengthening the company's market presence. His proven track record over the past year paved the way for this promotion to CEO. Ashish brings with him a wealth of experience spanning over two decades. Before JSW Paints, he spent more than 18 years at Unilever, where he held several key leadership roles including Head of Distributive Trade Transformation and Global Vice President for Distributive Trade & B2B E-commerce. During his tenure, he led strategic priorities in digital transformation and distributive trade across global markets, and also served as Managing Director of Unilever Nepal Limited. Earlier in his career, Ashish worked with Colgate Palmolive India as Account Manager for Modern Trade in the West and Area Sales Manager in Rajasthan, and began his professional journey as a Software Engineer at Infosys. Ashish's elevation reflects JSW Paints' confidence in his leadership and vision to accelerate growth in the decorative paints segment.

â€‰ Toothbrushes. I've used an expensive Oral-B iO, a cheap Chinese brand from Amazon, and basic non-electric brushes from Crest, Colgate, etc. The expensive Oral-B was disgusting. It had crevices that accumulated mold and slime and were impossible to clean. Lots of people online reported the same issue. It also required expensive brush head replacements every 3 months. I discarded the brush within a year because of the mold and gunk issue. The cheap electric brush had a simple design and thus was easy to clean. The brushing action was rougher compared to the expensive brush, but still good and seemed equally effective. I used it for a few years until it died. The basic brushes are trivial to clean, don't require charging, and cost maybe $10 per year for replacements. They work well enough. I use a one-touch timer on my phone to replicate the electric brushes' built-in timers. And they are easy to travel with since they don't require a charger. I don't miss electric brushes.

â€‰ From Waste to Worldwide Use: A Bold Commerce Initiative Powered by VTEX NEW YORK, July 08, 2025Â BUSINESS WIREÂ From landfill to Lions: what began as a project in one of the world's most polluted landscapes earned VTEX (NYSE: VTEX), the backbone of connected commerce, two Bronze Lions Awards at the 2025 Cannes Lions International Festival. Awarded in the 'Media (Use of Digital Platforms)' and 'Direct (Corporate Purpose & Social Responsibility)' categories, the wins recognized the RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA initiative as a bold collaboration between VTEX, Artplan, Desierto Vestido and Fashion Revolution, becoming a blueprint in enterprise circular commerce. In addition to the two Bronze Lions recognitions, RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA was also shortlisted in four additional categories. The Atacama Desert has become a global symbol of excess production, receiving more than 40,000 tons of retail waste every year, mainly from North America and Europe. RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA wasn't just about spotlighting a crisis. It was about proving the versatile power of digital commerce. Each garment was hand-selected, sanitized, and restored. Many were unworn, still bearing original brand tags. The inventory was redistributed at no cost, with consumers only paying for shipping. Winning two Bronze Lions over hundreds of submissions comes off the heels of VTEX, being recognized as the only vendor named a GartnerÂ® Customers' Choice in the 2025 Voice of the Customer for Digital Commerce report for the second year in a row. The Impact of RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA: Activated the first globally scalable circular commerce model from recovered desert fast fashion waste, and powered by a simplified and adaptable enterprise-grade digital commerce platform. Redistributed inventory to consumers in 10+ countries around the globe. Sold out inventory in just under five hours without paid media. Generated a whopping 200,000 signups for future waste drops. Delivered branded UX, storytelling, and packaging that sparked global connection and community towards a larger movement. Built in full collaboration: Desierto Vestido (recovery), Fashion Revolution Brazil (upcycle), Artplan (creative), VTEX (commerce engine). Mariano Gomide de Faria, Founder and Co-CEO of VTEX, said: "RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA winning two Bronze Lions at Cannes 2025 sends a clear message: commerce can do more than scale global enterprise brands. With the remarkable partnership of Artplan, Desierto Vestido, and Fashion Revolution, we have proven how adaptable digital commerce platforms can correct, redistribute, and challenge the logic of excess. At VTEX, we're proud to have disrupted the model of linear consumption. This is one of the most urgent and transformative campaigns we've been part of this year, and it signals to other digital commerce platforms that neutrality In the conversation of retail waste is no longer an option. RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA has set the standard for global impact as value is defined by what is recovered, not just by what is sold." Built for viability over virality, RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA is now evolving into a long-term solution. In partnership with the University of Chile, the next phase focuses on transforming volunteer roles into paid work, generating local income, and formalizing the recovery and redistribution of discarded garments. The goal is a sustainable environmental and economic model led by a strong community. As AI reshapes the future of commerce, RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA is a case study in purposeful design meeting adaptable digital infrastructure. When intention is rooted in impact, transformation scales. And what started in the desert is now a global benchmark for regenerative commerce powered by technology, community, and creativity. To learn more about the RE-COMMERCE ATACAMA initiative, click here. ABOUT US: VTEX (NYSE: VTEX) is the commerce suite of choice for bold CIOs and CEOs globally, delivering transformative outcomes with unprecedented operational efficiency. By unifying a comprehensive ecosystem of solutionsâ€”including B2C, B2B, Sales App, Pick & Pack, Data Pipeline, Retail Media, and Security Shieldâ€”VTEX empowers brands and retailers to eliminate friction, foster collaboration, and accelerate growth. More than just software, VTEX is an agent of transformation, seamlessly connecting customers, partners, and developers to drive tangible business results. Trusted by 2.4 thousand global B2C and B2B customers, including Carrefour, Colgate, Sony, Stanley Black & Decker, and Whirlpool, VTEX supports 3.4 thousand active online stores across 43 countries (FY ended December 31, 2024). For more information, visit . View source version on businesswire.com: Kate Adams PAN Communications for VTEX

â€‰ In this column, the usual roles are reversed, and I answer questions about my new book, â€œFranklin High School: Two Basketball Dynasties.â€ Question: What is your new book about? Answer: It is a book about the memoirs of Michael Ferrara. He was a legend in basketball in Sussex County during the 1970s. Q: What inspired the book? A: I caught up with Mike a year or so ago. He was keenly interested in recording his life in the sport of basketball and getting his experiences for others to have. As we are alumni of Franklin High School, we were aware that there were two times when basketball at our school was tremendously popular and successful. One era was in the 1950s or so with Coach Reginald Purdy. Another time was in the 1970s with the Stefkoviches and also Mike Ferrara. Q. Tell me about Ferrara. A. Mike grew up down near the city and his family moved to Pleasant Valley Lake in Vernon. He went to Franklin High School, which was still operating as such and had done so until the early 1980s. The kids now go to Wallkill Valley Regional High School. Mike became an outstanding player on the high school basketball team and went on to play at Colgate University and then was drafted into the NBA. Q: What are the highlights of his career? A. He started out in college at Niagara University and then moved to Colgate. While at Colgate, he scored 1,763 points, which was then a school record. He still holds the school record for points in a season, which is 772, and also the number of steals in a season of 94. He finished a very close second to the leading scorer in NCAA Division I during the 1980-81 season. During that time, Mike had a fantastic 28.6 points per game average. He was also named the Patriot Conference prestigious Player of the Year. Mike went on to be drafted by the Washington Bullets. He had a number of fascinating stories that he speaks about in the book. We also bring into play several of the important people in his life and athletic journey. Chiefly among them are the coaches he had. One was Coach Frank Virtue of his time at Franklin. Coach Virtue was beloved by many from the town. Through the book, Mike describes how influences by special people impacted his life, broadened his horizons and aided in the development as an exceptional player. Q. How is this book different from others you have written? A. This happens to be the seventh book that I have published. It is the first book where we were working on a memoir. The vigor that Mike had when we got together a year or so made me laugh. I had known him for some 40 years and he was always high-energy. But he still possessed the same level of enthusiasm and eagerness as way back when. He worked out daily near his home in Tampa, Fla., and had a strong regimen that he followed. Making the book was a fun time with him and interviewing our mutual old adviser, Coach Virtue. Q: Where can we get the book? A: â€œFranklin High School: Two Basketball Dynastiesâ€ is available at the Sparta Bookstore and Broad Street Books in Branchville. You also can get an e-version (Kindle) on Amazon along with a soft cover and a hard cover. Q: Any parting words? A: I certainly have mixed feelings on the book. You see, Mike, ole' #44 as he liked to be referred to (his retired number at Colgate), passed away on Sunday June 15. While he was full of his lifelong enthusiasm just a few months ago, he had been diagnosed with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), often called Lou Gehrig's disease. While we didn't know it at the beginning, we worked hard to get the book done as soon as we could. As it turned out, I was only awaiting his last â€œyesâ€ of approval on the back cover layout when he took deathly ill and was unable to reply with that one word. So, while the book is fantastic, the culmination was disheartening....

â€‰ NEW YORK (July 9, 2025) â€“â€¯The New York Sirens announced today that defender Allyson Simpson has been re-signed to a two-year Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL) Standard Player Agreement through the 2026-27 season. â€œKnowing that Allyson will be with us for at least the next two seasons adds to this wave of youth,â€ said Sirens General Manager Pascal Daoust. â€œIt's her talent, speed, and leadership that we're proud and excited to build with and around.â€ The 24-year-old from Fort Worth, Texas, was a constant presence on the ice in her rookie season, appearing in all 30 games after being selected by New York in the third round of the 2024 PWHL Draft. She tallied four assists and added one goal, finishing the year with five points which tied for fourth among rookie rearguards. â€œI'm thrilled to be re-signing with the Sirens as we continue to create something special with this organization,â€ said Simpson. â€œI'm excited to play a role in the league's continued growth while helping shape the Sirens into a championship team. I can't wait to get back on the ice with my teammates, old and new, and give everything I have for them and the fans who have supported us from day one.â€ Before turning pro, Simpson honed her skills under Head Coach Greg Fargo at Colgate University, where she played for five seasons. She appeared in 174 games and recorded 107 points, capped by a career-high 34 points (9G, 25A) in 40 games during the 2023-24 campaign. She led the Raiders to a Frozen Four berth after scoring the game-winning goal against Cornell. Internationally, Simpson won back-to-back gold medals with Team USA at the 2017 and 2018 IIHF U18 Women's World Championships. The 5'8â€ Simpson returns to a Sirens lineup that has five other defenders under contract for the 2025-26 season, including Lauren Bernard, Jaime Bourbonnais, Maja NylÃ©n Persson, Jincy Roese and captain Micah Zandee-Hart. Fans looking to stay up to date on ticket release dates, team announcements, and exclusive offers are encouraged to subscribe to The Beat, the official Sirens newsletter. For ticket related inquiries, please contact newyorkinfo@thepwhl.com. Click here for a full list of PWHL offseason transactions. ABOUT NEW YORK SIRENS The New York Sirens is one of eight teams in the newly launched Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL), which was founded in 2023. The PWHL began its inaugural season in January 2024 and features the best women's hockey players in the world. The PWHL has broken multiple attendance records and holds the worldwide record for a women's hockey game. For the latest news and information on the New York Sirens, visitâ€¯newyork.thepwhl.comâ€¯or follow the team onâ€¯Facebook,â€¯Instagram, andâ€¯X.â€¯Follow the league on all social media platforms @thepwhlofficial. ABOUT THE PROFESSIONAL WOMEN'S HOCKEY LEAGUE (PWHL) The Professional Women's Hockey League (PWHL) is a professional ice hockey league in North America comprised of eight teams in Boston, Minnesota, MontrÃ©al, New York, Ottawa, Toronto, Seattle and Vancouver, each with rosters featuring the best women's hockey players in the world. Launched on Jan. 1, 2024, the PWHL has broken multiple attendance records and holds the worldwide all-time record for a women's hockey game. In 2024, the PWHL was recognized by Sports Business Journal as the Sports Breakthrough of the Yearâ€¯and received the top position in the first-ever Canadian edition of the Harris Poll, which ranks companies' reputations. â€‰ Five Below is your one-stop shop for travel size toiletries. Not only do these items fit into even the most compact carry-on, they're all priced low enough to help shoppers save money. For You: 7 Little Luxuries To Buy at Five Below This July GOBankingRates reviewed Five Below's travel care department and pulled our top 12 affordable recommendations for your next flight. Price: $3 Need a sleeve of hand wipes for your trip? Pick up Wet Ones hand wipes for just $3. Each package includes 20 wipes with a wet lock seal to close and retain freshness when not in use. This comes out to paying about 15 cents per wipe. Check Out: 6 Costco Products That Have the Most Customer Complaints View Next: 21 Things To Buy at Dollar Tree This Summer If You Live on Social Security Price: $2 A trio of individually wrapped Kleenex tissues are a must for families on long flights to keep sneezes under control. At $2 per pack, this means Five Below shoppers pay only about 67 cents for each tissue sleeve. Try This: 3 Things Retirees Should Stop Buying To Save Money Amid Tariffs Price: $3 If there's not much space inside your carry-on, consider swapping out a regular-size or electric toothbrush with a folding travel toothbrush instead. These toothbrushes fold up easily to fit in toiletry bags. Hurry though: Just a few colors are still available to shop online. Price: $2 Along with buying a folding toothbrush, it's a good idea to pick up a travel-size Colgate toothpaste. This cheap mini toothpaste is extra handy for carry-on luggage in the event you get food stuck in your teeth during your flight and need to brush before arrival. Price: $2 No matter how long or short your flight is, it's always a good idea to keep a mini deodorant handy to freshen up. Secret deodorant is affordably priced and TSA checkpoint approved at 1.7 ounces. Trending Now: 11 Best New Groceries on Sale at Costco in July Price: $2 For the guys in your traveling party, it never hurts to have Old Spice deodorant handy. At 0.5 ounces, you'll have no trouble slipping one into your carry-on. Price: $2 Heading straight to the hotel after a long day of traveling and don't want to stop at a drugstore to grab toiletries? You're covered with Pantene Pro-V shampoo in a conveniently sized 3.38-ounce tube. Price: $5 What's nice about shopping for Vaseline mini lip tubs is they come in a value pack. Each package includes two mini tubs. Price: $5 Snooze away a long flight in a weighted eye mask. Only pink, green and blue styles are available to shop, so snag one while they're still in stock. Price: $4 You might stand outside for a bit to book rideshares once your flight arrives and, for those moments, you'll be glad you packed a travel size sunscreen. The Sun Bum brand is $4 and features SPF 30 to protect skin from harsh UV rays. Price: $3 Freshen up your face before arriving at your destination with Clarisse makeup remover towelettes. Each sleeve is filled with 30 towelettes designed for all skin types. That's Interesting: I'm a Shopping Expert â€” These 10 Items Are the Best Frugal Buys at Costco Price: $3 Depending where you shop, pill cases and organizers can cost upward of $7. Not at Five Below, where shoppers can pick up a bubble pill case for just $3 apiece. Store all of your prescriptions, vitamins and OTC meds in the pill case's six compartments and save a little extra room in your carry-on that would have otherwise been occupied by bottles and boxes. â€‰ Shopping writer Lucy Addicott has chosen her top five electric toothbrush deals for Amazon Prime Day 2025 with one contender saving shoppers more than Â£300 This article contains affiliate links, we will receive a commission on any sales we generate from it. Learn more Shoppers making the move from manual to electric toothbrushes might want to dive into Amazon Prime Day 2025's oral-care offers as there are some sparkling deals on top brands. The likes of Oral-B and Philips have slashed the prices on some of their gadgets, providing a great opportunity to upgrade a dental routine for less. With discounts of up to Â£310 off, there are some serious savings to be had and as a shopping writer who has tried and tested over five electric toothbrushes from Oral-B, SURI and more, my hand-picked deals make spotting the best ones a whole lot easier. While a manual brush can do the job, they have nothing on their tech counterparts in terms of ease, functionality and overall results. As the average person spends more than 80 days in their life cleaning their teeth, it's well worth investing in a high quality brush - and these deals mean you don't have to spend a fortune. READ MORE: 'I'm a beauty writer - the new ghd curling wand gave me perfect waves in 15 mins' READ MORE: The best electric toothbrush tested as Oral-B, Philips and Ordo compared To take advantage of the deals customers will need to be a member of Amazon Prime. Those that are not can sign up for a free 30 day trial and enjoy discounts during the duration of Amazon Prime Day. Elsewhere, Oral-B are also running a summer sale, with bundles including free toothbrush heads, toothpaste, mouthwash and more. It is also Boots 'super savings week' and shoppers can find discounts on electricals from brush-baby, Oral-B, Colgate and Philips. Free Amazon Prime membership Â£8.99 Free Amazon Get Prime here Amazon Prime membership, including exclusive Prime Day discounts and perks on Hello Fresh, music, books and Prime Video. Usually Â£8.99 a month, you can now get a 30-day free trial to get access to the latest deals. Oral-B iO2 Electric Toothbrush, now Â£40, was Â£100 With a 60% off discount, the Oral-B iO2 model is now Â£39.99 reduced from Â£100. This beats the price of Boots and the Oral-B website, where it is on sale for Â£45. It's a top of the range toothbrush as it boasts three brushing modes (daily clean, sensitive and super sensitive), a gum pressure sensor and a 30 second timer letting the user know when to clean a different part of the mouth. It also comes with a travel case, for less than Â£40 all in. There are various different colours in stock, from black to white, plus spending Â£3 extra means customers can get a sturdier case with a special design. One shopper was left very impressed with the 'long lasting battery' and another said its 'smooth and quiet clean' has 'exceeded expectations'. Someone else said the 'vibration feels a little rough', but they got used to the sensation 'pretty quickly'. Oral-B iO8 Electric Toothbrush, now Â£139, was Â£450 Saving shoppers more than Â£300, the Oral-B iO8 can be snapped up for Â£139.99, down from Â£450. Nearly 70% off, this mega deal has been hailed 'good value for money' as it is a 'five star toothbrush'. Features include six cleaning modes (daily clean, sensitive, whiten, gum care, intense and super sensitive) and sensor alerts. Oral-B's iO8 model takes things up a notch in terms of dentalcare as it boasts AI intelligence, recognising your brushing style and guiding you via an app. The real-time feedback is 'impressive' and 'by far the best' for some, while others found it 'not necessary'. SURI Electric Toothbrush, now Â£56, was Â£75 The SURI Sustainable Electric Toothbrush is the device I have been using for the last two years - and it's still serving me well. I find it is reducing my cost of hygienist visits and I've even has friends ask me where I got the toothbrush from when away on trips. On sale at Amazon for Â£56.25, it is incredibly lightweight, making it perfect for travel, and it comes in four stylish colours. The eco-friendly gadget has been designed to clean teeth with a minimal impact on the environment, using brush heads made from plant-based materials. It is important to note that users will have to stick to the SURI brush heads and you can pick up a pack of three for Â£14.99. The brand also offers a brush head subscription service. SURI toothbrushes are also 25% off on their website as part of the summer sale. Shoppers can read my full review here. Philips Sonicare 6100 Electric Toothbrush, now Â£99, was Â£290 Having tried the Philips Sonicare DiamondClean Prestige 9900, I can vouch that the brand make an exceptional toothbrush. This model in particular is on sale for Prime, but is still at the pricier end of the scale at Â£199.99, down from Â£267. Those looking to spend under Â£100 can nab the Philips Sonicare 6100 model for Â£99.99, reduced from Â£290. A saving of Â£200, the toothbrush comes with two spare brush heads and a nifty travel case. â€‰ CBA forward Jack Donohue could be the latest in a line of former Siena ball boys to make their names as Division I basketball players. Donohue worked as a Saints ball boy for four seasons. He began under former coach Mitch Buonaguro and continued for Jimmy Patsos, a friend of Donohue's father, Darren. "It was great," Jack Donohue said. "I loved it. At halftime, you're able to play. When you roll out the balls, you're able to shoot a little bit before you get in trouble. It was fun to be out on the court, like you were a Division I athlete at the age of 10." It's possible Donohue, entering his junior year of high school, could make MVP Arena his home in college. Siena coach Gerry McNamara has offered him a scholarship. But the Saints have growing competition for Donohue, who is 6-foot-7 and 215 pounds. He has been offered by several other schools, including the University at Albany, Bryant and Pennsylvania. Bryant coach Jamion Christian and Penn coach Fran McCaffery are former Siena coaches. "He's a very good shooter," said dad Darren, a Shaker graduate. "He's very tangible, is what all the coaches say. He can rebound, he can run, he's strong and he can really shoot the ball well." Jack Donohue said he's talking to Siena, UAlbany, Penn, Bryant and La Salle about setting up official visits in August and September. He's also speaking with Colgate and Harvard. Assuming he gets to Division I, Donohue will continue a Siena ball boy tradition. McCaffery's sons Connor and Patrick served that role for the Saints before following their father to his next job at Iowa. They played for him with the Hawkeyes. Brothers Kevin and Thomas Huerter were also Siena ball boys. Kevin spent two seasons at Maryland, became a NBA first-round draft pick and now plays for the Chicago Bulls. Thomas played for Siena, his father Tom's alma mater. Siena offered Donohue last month. "To be local and have such a great program, and the history of the program be held on a pedestal, it's great to be having them reach out to me," he said. "The relationship's grown since then. They're always reaching out to me, which is nice." The Donohues credit much of Jack's development to his play with the New Jersey Shoreshots, an AAU program directed by former Rutgers and Robert Morris coach Mike Rice. Donahue played this spring for the 16-and-under team. Quinton Redding, his 16U coach, said he watched Donohue develop from a catch-and-shoot player into someone who has the confidence to put the ball on the floor and become a stronger rebounder. "I feel like he was maybe just trying to fit in, and told him just to be himself," Redding said. "He's here for a reason. Once he heard that advice, he did his thing and took off." Redding said Donohue had his breakout performance at an Under Armour tournament in Hamilton, Ohio in May. He shot better than 40% from 3-point range and rebounded well. "I think he's a mid-major (college prospect) right now and, by the time he gets to his senior year, he has the potential to be a Power Five player," Redding said. Darren, his father, said Stanford and Notre Dame have reached out, but without offers, so far. Jack Donohue gets at least some of his height and talent from his mother, Danielle (Galarneau) Donohue, a 6-foot-1 Troy native. She's in the Marist Hall of Fame after scoring 1,141 points and grabbing 833 rebounds for the Red Foxes. "She played down in the post, so anytime I have any questions about being a post player, or just footwork-wise down low, I always go to her because I know how successful she was on the court," Jack said. He returns next season to a talented CBA team that includes star teammate JJ Osinski, son of former Siena star Corey Osinski. When was a ball boy, Jack Donohue envisioned playing for Siena. He's getting closer to reaching Division I, whether for the Saints or somewhere else. "Just playing at that level alone was a dream of mine," he said. "To now be living it, it's pretty cool." â€‰ Priya Nair's elevation is met with optimism from brokerages, who expect her to steer HUL through competitive pressures and unlock new growth avenues. This is first time a woman will lead the FMCG giant in its 92-year history. Investors and brokerages are cheering India's largest fast moving consumer goods player Hindustan Unilever Ltd's (HUL) latest CEO and MD Priya Nair, who will replace the current chief Rohit Jawa, starting August 1, 2025. HUL announced the appointment of Priya Nair as its new Chief Executive Officer and Managing Director, making her the first woman to lead the FMCG giant in its 92-year history. She is currently President, Beauty & Wellbeing, Unilever. Story continues below In an exchange filing, the FMCG major said that she replaces Rohit Jawa, who will step down as CEO and MD on July 31, 2025 to pursue the next chapter in his personal and professional journey. According to analysts, Priya Nair will provide the FMCG player with the required boost to navigate the rising competitive challenges, whileÂ accelerating HUL's digital transformation efforts. Further, with her long-standing experience at HUL, she is well-positioned to help the firm capitalize on the evolving and long-term prospects of the Indian consumption market, stated Japan-based Nomura. The brokerage offered an example from Priya Nair's stint in the Home Care segment from 2014 to 2020. During this time, the segment's EBIT margin soared 570 basis points from 13.1 percent in FY14, to 18.8 percent in FY20. As a result, HUL's overall EBIR margin rose from 15 percent to 22.3 percent over the years. From 2020 to 2022, Priya Nair was instrumental in HUL's premiumization thrust. She drove the shift fromÂ from value offerings to the premium segment by driving 26 percent of HUL's portfolio focus towards premium demand spacesÂ compared to 20 percentÂ in 2020. With Nair stepping to the helm, HUL is likely to enter a new phase of growth and innovation, notedÂ Nitin Paranjpe, Chairman, HUL. This will be very closely watched by experts, who have often voiced concerns around the FMCG player's underperformance compared to peers. Thanking Jawa for his contributions, Nitin Paranjpe, Chairman, HUL, said, â€œOn behalf of the Board, I thank Rohit for steering the company through a challenging market and laying the foundations for future success. His strategic clarity and decisive actions further strengthened HUL's leadership.â€ Story continues below He added, â€œPriya has had an exemplary career across HUL and Unilever. With her deep knowledge of the Indian consumer and a global perspective, I am confident she will lead HUL into a new phase of growth and innovation.â€ Over the past five years, shares of HUL have recorded a mere eight percent uptick. However, the change should bring some comfort to the firm's stock price. Citi Research noted that management changes in the Indian consumer space have been a much talked about factor on Street. Further, in recent memory, the markets saw big rallies and eventual business performance improvements at Godrej Consumer and Colgate India, following a change in management. According to Goldman Sachs, HUL's volume growth will gradually improve over FY26. Morgan Stanley and Investec, both, noted that the departure of Rohit Jawa came as a surprise, given his shorter-than-expected stint. The brokerages also pointed to a recent reshuffle in HUL parent Unilever's CEO, with the former CEO stepping down in February. Macquarie, however, allayed concerns, noting that while the sudden departure of Rohit Jawa and the relatively short period of transition remain concerning, the brokerage gains comfort from Priya's long period of experience in India. Further, the change of guard will drive a stronger focus on growth, especially in the Beauty segment. â€‰ Background: I got braces at a very young age, I might have been 9 maybe. I believe I had them for 4 - 5 years. (Got them early bc of a surgery I had.) During this time, I neglected my oral hygiene and that led me to develop many cavities. Maybe around 20, I know, a lot. I ended up getting them filled not too long after. I was still left with weak enamel. Fast forward a few years later, I ended up having to get a gum graft. WORST experience ever. It was awful and I don't want to go through it again. I have tried to do everything. I try to floss daily. Brush 1 - 2 times a day. Enamel toothpaste burns so I just don't use it, I just stick to Colgate because it doesn't burn and seems to help a little bit. I do a water + salt rinse. Once a week I do a water + hydrogen peroxide mix. And on top of that I do oil pulling before I brush every night. I'm about to go to the dentist this week but I wanted opinions and suggestions before hand. I have had multiple dentists and they all said many different things. Some say you can reverse recession, others said I can't. Currently 18, and I'm scared that all of these cavities and neglect from when I was younger are going to lead to root canal's, crowns, more gum grafts, or extraction of the tooth in general. Is there any way I can keep my real teeth throughout the majority of my lifetime even with the current damage at a young age.

FLEMING, CEO AND PRESIDENT Gregory J. Fleming is the Chief Executive Officer of Rockefeller Capital Management, a role he has held since the firm, formerly known as Rockefeller & Co., launched in March 2018. He is also a member of the Board of Directors. Prior to leading Rockefeller Capital Management, Greg was the President of Morgan Stanley Wealth Management and Morgan Stanley Investment Management. Before joining Morgan Stanley in 2010, he served as President and Chief Operating Officer of Merrill Lynch, from 2007 to 2009, and previously ran Merrill Lynch's Global Investment Banking business. Greg joined Merrill Lynch as an investment banker in 1992. He had also been a principal at Booz Allen Hamilton. He is a former director of Colgate University, a member of the Board of Advisors for the Yale Law School Center for the Study of Corporate Law; a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a member of the Economic Club of New York and a trustee at Deerfield Academy. He also serves as a Resource Council member of the Turn 2 Foundation and serves on the Advisory Board of COVR, an innovative financial services startup. Greg is a Phi Beta Kappa, summa cum laude graduate of Colgate University with a bachelor's degree in Economics. He received his J.D. from Yale Law School. â€‰ The Boston Celtics used their first round pick in the 2025 NBA draft, No. 28 overall, on Hugo Gonzalez, a 6'6 wing from Spain who they hope can come in and impact the franchise right away while they wait for superstar Jayson Tatum to recover from his torn Achilles. Gonzalez starred overseas for Real Madrid, and was briefly teammates with incoming Gonzaga freshman guard Mario Saint-Supery, who committed to Mark Few's club in early July. Gonzalez spoke highly of the 19-year-old guard in a conversation with Theo Lawson of the Spokesman-Review at NBA Summer League on Friday, saying Gonzaga is "going to get a slasher that's really, really aggressive." "Really good defender on ball," Gonzalez continued. "He's also a big competitor. We're both really, really competitive." Celtics first-round pick Hugo Gonzalez on Spanish nat'l teammate/new #Gonzaga guard Mario Saint-Supery: "They're going to get a slasher that's really, really aggressive. Really good defender on ball. He's also a big competitor. We're both really, really competitive." Saint-Supery has long been connected to Mark Few and the Zags, with rumors swirling about the 6'4 guard coming to Spokane way back in April. Saint-Supery is the latest international find for Gonzaga's coaching staff, who have an incredibly rich history of bringing in talent from overseas - including Rui Hachimura, Filip Petrusev, Killian Tillie, Pryzemek Karnowski, Ronny Turiaf, Joel Ayayi, and Elias Harris among many others. Saint-Supery starred for Spain in the 2024 FIBA U18 EuroBasket event, averaging over 21 points per game along with six assists and five rebounds. Compared to Ricky Rubio due to his elite passing skills, Saint-Supery is an excellent fit in Few's high-octane, heavy ball movement offensive sets. While Colgate transfer Braeden Smith, who redshirted last year behind Ryan Nembhard, is projected to be Gonzaga's starter at point guard this year, Saint-Supery should get plenty of run right away for the Zags and could play his way into a bigger role as the season goes on, particularly as he gets comfortable in the new system, and new country. Copyright 2025 The Arena Group, Inc. All Rights Reserved This story was originally published July 13, 2025 at 5:46 PM.

Saint-Supery is the latest international find for Gonzaga's coaching staff, who have an incredibly rich history of bringing in talent from overseas - including Rui Hachimura, Filip Petrusev, Killian Tillie, Pryzemek Karnowski, Ronny Turiaf, Joel Ayayi, and Elias Harris among many others. Saint-Supery starred for Spain in the 2024 FIBA U18 EuroBasket event, averaging over 21 points per game along with six assists and five rebounds. Compared to Ricky Rubio due to his elite passing skills, Saint-Supery is an excellent fit in Few's high-octane, heavy ball movement offensive sets. While Colgate transfer Braeden Smith, who redshirted last year behind Ryan Nembhard, is projected to be Gonzaga's starter at point guard this year, Saint-Supery should get plenty of run right away for the Zags and could play his way into a bigger role as the season goes on, particularly as he gets comfortable in the new system, and new country. This story was originally reported by Athlon Sports on Jul 14, 2025, where it first appeared.

â€‰ Yeah unfortunately a lot of us are worried about getting a Covid infection but there is not much available to the average punter to help. I agree with others that Paxlovid is ideal if your doctor agrees. Even getting some IV fluids or simliar may help give you a pick me up. Paxlovid may have some side effects on your gut. The other medication may prevent long covid from acute covid is Metformin. [https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(23)00299-2/fulltext](https://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(23)00299-2/fulltext) Some other options that seem to show promise but have less evidence are antihistamines ([https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9903129/](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9903129/)), probiotics, an antiviral nasal spray (e.g. with carrageenan), and mounthwash with CPC (e.g. colgate plax). Allergies could indicate MCAS which is generally helped by type 1 and 2 antihistamines alongside mast cell stabilisers such as ketotifen and cromolyn sodium.
